dialogues.speaker: CARD
dialogues.text: In darkness we hear:

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Forster... How can I give you the faintest notion of my reception here in America?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A STAGE MANAGER knocks and calls out in a Brooklyn accent

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Five minutes...five minutes Ink stained fingers fumble with silver CUFF LINKS. A pair BOOTS is smartly buffed. A brightly coloured SILK SCARF i adjusted.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Of the crowds that pour in and out the whole day; of the people that line the streets when I go out... In the mirror, the writer (CHARLES DICKENS) looking like English rock star in his prime (silk blouse, tight trouse velvet jacket), fusses with the locks on his forehead, th steps back and regards himself critically.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ....of the balls, dinners, speeches, parties, assemblies without end. There never was a king or Emperor upon the Earth, so cheered. He breaks into a wide grin.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: ‘Ello, Charlie. Another knock at the door breaks the moment.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Places, please. Places. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 2

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have had deputations from the Far West, who have come from more than two thousand miles distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens moves along the corridor. The sounds of the crowd stomping their feet and clapping their hands gets louder he nears the stage.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They come from the lakes, the rivers, the back-woods, the log- houses, the cities, factories, villages and towns- A PRESENTER is making a flowery introduction on stage. Th sound of the crowd is deafening.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENTER
dialogues.text: .+..The great magician of our time, whose wand is a book. The Shakespeare of the novel. The people's author. Dickens reaches the wings. He breathes in deeply through nose, steadying himself. He nods at the Stage Manager.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ... the one and only, the inimitable, the great and marvellous Boz! Ladies and gentlemen- Mr. Charles Dickens! The stagehands raise the curtain. Dickens takes a deep br and steps into the light. At the sight of him, the audien rises to its feet as one. Behind him “TABLEAUX VIVANTS” appear, depicting sights an scenes of London, Beef Eaters roll out canons, characters from Oliver Twist come to life, urchins dance along to th band. Dickens taking this in. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 3

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Americans are friendly, earnest, hospitable, kind, frank, accomplished, warm-hearted, fervent and enthusiastic... Uncertainly, he raises his arms above his head. The crowd goes wilder still, BLANKETING the stage with flowers and SCREAMING “BOZ, BOZ, BOZ"”. Dickens attempts to speak to the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Dear friends, you have welcomed me to your country with such open arms that I fear that I- But his speech is cut off by a deafening volley as the cannons behind him fire ticker tape into the air. Dickens shrinks, covering his ears.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can't wait to get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens sits at his desk, pen in hand, in front of a blan piece of paper, as if willing something to appear. After a moment, he throws the pen down and gets up to loo the mirror, making a face. He picks up an ACCORDION and plays a few squeaky NOTES.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (sings) Yanky doodle, doodle dandy Turn right round in the bottom of the gangy- There is a tentative KNOCK at the door. He throws it open frustration.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Fisk. I have told you repeatedly not to disturb me when I'm working.  The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 8, 2016 MRS. FISK, the housekeeper, a rather severe Scotswoman, i taken aback. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FISK
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon sir. Only, Mr. Forster is here.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I'll be right down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front hall is full of workmen, including the energeti SIGNOR MAZZINI, who is busy directing traffic, as various the DICKENS CHILDREN run in and out of the chaos.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNOR MAZZINI
dialogues.text: Adesso! Subito! Veni qui! Kate gives a tour to Dickens’ friend and de facto literar manager, JOHN FORSTER -- a big, pleasant-looking man with Geordie accent.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You see, Mr. Forster, we’re having all new wallpaper. French. New doors, new roller blinds for the windows, new book-cases in the library, all chosen by Charles, of course. And the staircase is to be painted green (to Signor Mazzini) — though not too dull a green, Signor Mazzini.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNOR MAZZINI
dialogues.text: Si, si. Capice.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (to Forster) You know how Charles is.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: The best is good enough for me!

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I wish he’d redecorate that study of his. It’s like an animal’s den. But he won’t let anyone touch it! Two workmen pass between them carrying a large chandelier. 4 The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: 4A
dialogues.text: Workman Scusi. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 5

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Mr. Forster. If you will allow me: how do things stand between you and Miss Wigmore?

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Splendid, Mrs. Dickens. In fact, I intend to ask her to bestow upon me the greatest happiness a man can ever know. Kate stares at him, uncomprehending.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To marry me.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Ooh! She embraces him, causing him to flush a deep crimson.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am very glad to hear it. Dickens comes thundering down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Forster. Good Lord. I completely lost track of the time. Kate puts out a hand.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Charles. We need to pay Signor Mazzini. For the parlour mantle.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: SIGNOR MAZZINI
dialogues.text: Seventy-five pounds. Dickens staggers back.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Seventy-five — what is it made of, gold?

dialogues.speaker: SIGNOR MAZZINI
dialogues.text: Carrara marble, Signor. Finest quality. No gentleman would accept less. Beat. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 6

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I’ll have the money for you when I return, Signor Mazzini. Dickens turns to Forster.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shall we? Forster bows to Kate.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Good day, Mrs. Dickens.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Good day, Mr. Forster. Dickens is nearly out the door, where a WORKMAN is busy attaching a shiny new knocker.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: I‘1l hail us a cab.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Waste of money. We’1ll walk.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Walk? Are you mad? Dickens rushes out, followed by Forster. They head down t street at pace, the London skyline in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: The best way to lengthen our days is to walk steadily and with a purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A publishing house in The Strand. In the outside office, nervous young CLERK listens to a heated conversation in t other room.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, we don’t seem to understand one another. I asked you a simple question: where is the money?

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The money, Mr. Forster— The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes. Money. You know: Pounds, shillings, stumpy, shiners, joeys— A huge CRASH, then silence. The clerk winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forster stands by an overturned tea trolley. Crockery everywhere. He gestures apologetically at the two publish CHAPMAN (rather portly and florid ) and HALL (tall and angular).

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: I do apologize. He attempts to pick up the broken crockery.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bull in a china shop.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Please don’t trouble yourself. Forster resumes his tirade.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Charles Bloody Dickens! The best- selling bloody author in the history of English bloody literature — He gestures towards Dickens. Dickens’ lips are pressed together, his attention on a magazine publication. The headline on it reads “Martin Chuzzlewit, A Tedious Journe

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Three of his books you've published in the last year and a half. Three. So— where is the money?

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Forster. Like you, we are as Puzzled as the Egyptians in their Fog.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Howzat?

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: The Excitement with which a Popular Reputation is Kept up to the Highest Selling Mark will always be Subject to Lulls too Capricious for Explanation. 7 The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 8

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Ahm still not followin’.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: —Martin Chuzzlewit— a Masterpiece of the Picaresque Genre— and Yet—

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: Barnaby Rudge— a Fine Book— an Important Subject— But— alas—

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: And The Travel book— “American Notes”—

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: Perhaps— a Little Too Candid for our American Cousins—

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: No joke. I heard they were burning copies in the streets. Forster notices Dickens pained look.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mad as snakes, the Yanks. Forster renews his attack.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And what about this fifty pounds a month you’re withholding from his royalties? What’s the explanation for that? The two publishers squirm uncomfortably. Chapman produces contract and peers at it to cover his nervousness.

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: You May Remember that when Mr. Dickens Approached us about the Tour to America, we were Pleased to Provide Him with an Interest-Free Loan — He falters. Chapman continues.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: With the Provision That— In the Unlikely Case of Profits being Inadequate to Certain Repayments— Forster erupts. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 9

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Oh, divven’t hoy me that ket, you sackless mairks. The publishers exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, he’s had a few flops, who hasn’t? Your publishing house wouldn't exist without this man! Chapman gives Dickens a nervous look.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Actually, we do have a Suggestion—

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: - very Popular with the Reading Public —

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Perhaps Mr. Dickens might consider—

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: — and a lot of Money to be Made in-

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: — a Railway Edition of his works? Dickens is frowning.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: You're not serious? Those cheap yellow-backed jobs? With adverts for fig syrup on the cover? They all watch as Dickens gets to his feet. He turns the magazine publication over to obscure his bad Chuzzlewit review.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What about an advance?

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: -- on?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (bluffing) ..-A new book.

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: You have a New Book in mind?

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Of course he does... The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 10

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Well, in that case, obviously. We'd Love to Consider it...

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Consider it?

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: That is to say, If we Like it--

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: If?

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: I’m sure we will--

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. I bid you good day. He sweeps out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Forster: Please. We had no Intention of Causing Offense.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Ay. He’s in a fettle now. Give him a day to calm down —

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: And then... It's Most Awkward... “He” was in last week. In some Difficulty. Again.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: No, that’s not possible. He’s in the countryside. Under strict instructions to remain there. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it this time? Chapman hands him a letter and an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reading) “,..need money immediately or productive of fatal consequences... I beseech you to do the needful...” Forster shakes the envelope, causing several SLIPS OF PAP to fall out, each one torn from a letter, each with a signature: Charles Dickens. Forster makes a face. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 12 13 11

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: He’s been Offering Mr. Dickens’ Autographs for Sale in the Newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: How much did you give him?

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Forty-five, All Told.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Forty-five! — I‘'1l pay you back for it. Not a word of this to Charles, do you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Georgian building near Covent Garden, once a private ho now a gentlemen’s club, with a brass plate beside the doo THE GARRICK CLUB. And underneath, the motto: “ALL THE WOR A STAGE.” FORSTER rushes in, umbrella in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cozy dining room, typical of a Victorian men’s club. Be the bar, a group of SMART YOUNG MEN are gathered, gossipi and making quips. At the centre of the group is a tall fe with a braying laugh (WILLIAM MAKEPEACE THACKERAY). Dickens stands by the cloak room, holding a newspaper in front of his face.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Charles? Dickens folds down a corner of the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Shhh...

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: What are you doing over here? Dickens gestures towards the group.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I’m hiding. From Thackeray. He’ll want to commiserate with me on my Chuzzlewit reviews. Which he will quote by heart. Forster walks into the dining room. Dickens scuttles afte him, taking care not to be seen by Thackeray. Forster gra chair and cranes his head around. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Where’s Robertson? I’m clammin’ for some scran. Dickens slinks into another chair.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Why do we come here? The service is terrible. The food is inedible. And the fees keep going up — An elderly WAITER appears and bows low, losing his He fixes his gaze somewhere above their heads.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: You're not Robertson.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: The name is Marley, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Marley? Dickens gets out a pencil and a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With an e? The waiter’s eyes flicker with apprehension.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. He collects names. Let’s have some oysters. And a bottle of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Very good, sir. The waiter exits, at a stately pace.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Champagne?

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: We're celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: THACKERAY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Celebrating? 12 balance. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 13 Thackeray has somehow materialized at their table, an evi glint in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Thackeray. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: THACKERAY
dialogues.text: Tolerable I thank ye. Charles. I must say, I’m relieved to see you out and about.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Relieved?

dialogues.speaker: THACKERAY
dialogues.text: You know. After those vile things they wrote about Chuzzlewit. I won't even call them reviews.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No matter, I never read them. Forster shoots him a skeptical look. He waits.

dialogues.speaker: THACKERAY
dialogues.text: Quite right. Scandalous, what one is allowed to print nowadays. Dickens grits his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Why? What did they say?

dialogues.speaker: THACKERAY
dialogues.text: “Dull, vapid, and vulgar... Not a single character capable of exciting the reader's sympathy.” (beat) I certainly didn’t think it was vulgar. Dickens gives him a tight smile. THACKERAY (CONT’D) Oh, look! There’s Macready. Poor thing. His Macbeth was absolutely shredded in The Times. I must go and give him my condolences. Thackeray wafts away to rejoin the group at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I’m sick of London. Over-crowded, over-priced-- The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 14

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: -You love this town-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: - no place for a man without money. Not to mention the bloody fog--

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: It’s your inspiration. You’re what-— do-you-call it? Magic lantern. The waiter arrives. He opens the bottle with some difficu then bangs a plate of oysters down on the table and leave

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I tell you, Forster, my lamp’s gone out. I’ve run out of ideas. I feel old.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Old. Whssht. You’re a puppy. Forster pours some champagne.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're exhausted, that’s what. Too Many speeches.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I’ve got one tomorrow, for the Children’s Refuge.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: You have to learn to say no.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: How can I? If I can be useful.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: You'll have to. What with your new commission.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Forster, I just told you— He stops himself.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: — what commission?

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: From Chapman and Hall. For your next book. Forster grins and hands him a cheque. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 14 15 15

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I told them you'd have the first chapter by the end of the year. You like a deadline. Dickens stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Do you mind telling me what it's about?

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Oh, I leave that up to youse. He grins and helps himself to the oysters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens goes through a complicated pre-writing ritual: straightening everything on his desk, paper, ink, pen kni quills; then rapidly touching his desk ornaments one by o a CUP with fresh flowers in it, a pair of BRONZE TOADS, a RABBIT, and a CERAMIC MONKEY. He places a blank sheet in front of him, dips his pen in then stares at the paper, once again willing something to appear. INK drips slowly from the pen onto the page. He hears a strange, unearthly cry coming from nearby.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ul-ul-alul-alu! He opens the door, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens descends the stairs to the nursery. A young nursemaid, TARA is telling a bedtime story to the childre a soft Irish lilt.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: .-. And on Christmas Eve, they say, the fairy mounds open wide, and the fire spirits pour into the night... and then the Lord of the Dead leads all of the spirits in a Wild Hunt. And he calls to them... She throws back her head.

dialogues.speaker: TARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ul-ul-alul-alu! The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 16 16 CHARLIE age 10, Dickens’s oldest son, shivers with excite and dread. Dickens lingers a moment, mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens is in bed, going through the accounts book, while Kate reads a book called Roughing it in the Bush.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Do we have a new housemaid?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What? Oh, yes. Tara. She’s Irish. Charley adores her. The candle sputters. She lights a new one.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What are you doing? She shows him the stub of the old candle.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It was only a stub.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: There’s another hour in that.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Oh, really, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: If you carry on like this, we’ll end up in the Poor House. Kate laughs.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You are funny.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I’m not joking.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Charles. You give money to any and every beggar on the street. You insist on moving to a bigger house, and order all new fixtures, and then you complain about a new candle. Dickens speaks with a fervid intensity. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I know whereof I speak, Kate. Debt is -— an ogre. If you’re not careful it can eat you up. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Are we in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No. Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Then what — ?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Nothing. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sick of writing tooth and nail for bread, that’s all. Kate has heard this before. She goes back to her book.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Mmmm...

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I should have become a journalist.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You hate the press.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Or a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: “The law is an ass.” I believe you wrote that.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: A hairdresser, then. In the Burlington Arcade. “Hair Shampooed on the Oxford system.” Kate smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Do you know what I should have liked to be? Referring to her book— 2016 17 The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 17 18

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: An explorer. Paddling a canoe. Somewhere in the wilds of Canada. In a pair of buckskin breeches... All on my own... No nappies to change... She glances at Dickens, lost in his own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By the way, dear... I saw the doctor today. This gets his attention.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Not- another Little Stranger? She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Are you pleased? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Of course! Splendid. He stares straight ahead for a moment, then blows out the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A match flares and touches the wick of a magic lantern.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And now for this year’s Christmas present! Above it, the genial face of a middle-aged man appears, ( we will come to know as JOHN DICKENS). He is dressed in t elaborate headdress of a stage magician.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: I am the necromancer, Rhia Rhama Rhoos, educated cabalistically in the Orange Groves of Salamanca. Behold! He CLAPS his hands, theatrically. YOUNG CHARLES (AGE 10) and his six brothers and sisters a settled in front of a sheet hanging from the clothes hors The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 18 19 19 Behind them we can see a table set for Christmas dinner w holly and mistletoe. Mr. Dickens slips a painted slide into the magic lantern an image appears on the sheet: an angel, hovering above a group of shepherds.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Ohhh... Then, a bearded hunter, with a stag over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ahhh.... Then, Aladdin and his lantern.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hooray! On the faces of the children, there is a look of utter enchantment, but most particularly Young Charles. A terrifying ghost appears next. Young Charles covers his face with his hands.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARLES
dialogues.text: No. Go away. Mr. Dickens puts his hand on the young boy’s head to comf him. Mr. DICKENS It’s all right, Charlie. I’m here. You're safe. Young Charles climbs into his father’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. Now. I’1l show you how to get rid of bad spirits. Ready? They CLAP their hands together. The light on the magic lantern goes out, and the Ghost disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens awakes from his dream. Beside him, Kate sleeps peacefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dickens children, Charley, MAMIE (age 5), KATE (4), WALTER (age 3) line up for inspection. Dickens bowls in u a different voice to talk to each child, starting with Ma The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 20

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Mistress Chickenstalker. How are you this fine morning? She giggles.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is the matter with your pinnie? It looks as if you have been caught in a cyclone. She straightens it. He moves on to Walter, standing as straight as he can. Dickens salutes.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Master Corporal Skittles. Sir. He stares fixedly at Walter’s shoes.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ahem. The little boy self-consciously rubs one on the back of h leg. Dickens nods, approvingly. He moves on to Kate.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello, Lucifer Box.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Hello, Papa. Dickens offers her his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Would you do me the honour? She blows her nose. He arrives at Charley, clinging to the leg of Tara.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A-ha. The Snodgering Blee. We meet at last. Charley shrinks behind Tara.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Morning, Pa. Dickens inspects him up and down. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 20 21

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Much better, sir. But... What’s this? You forgot to wash behind your ears. Dickens pulls a coin from Charley’s ear, to his delight.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Cor! Dickens turns his attention to Tara.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Tara, is it?

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Dickens notes the look of adoration on Charley's face. Dickens I see you’ve made a conquest. Tara ruffles Charley's hair. Dickens (CONT’D) What were you telling the children last night? About the fairies? Tara glances at Mrs. Fisk, nervously.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Only a story my gran used to tell us, sir. Back home in Ireland. She used to say that on Christmas Eve the veil between this world and the next thins out. And that’s when the spirits cross over, and walk among us. Dickens reflects on this.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Do they indeed? INT/EXT. FREEMASON’S HALL - NIGHT 20 On the interior steps of the great hall, a sign announces Benefit for the Children’s Refuge. With Charles Dickens.” Well-dressed PATRONS stream out. Dickens walks out of the hall, shaking hands with a haugh Society Woman. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 22

dialogues.speaker: SOCIETY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming. Such an interesting speech. Another couple of SOCIETY LADIES go by, whispering.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIETY LADY
dialogues.text: ... not nearly as handsome as I'd thought... A red-faced industrialist, GRIMSBY, and his star-struck W approach.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRIMSBY
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Dickens. It is such an honour to meet you. Mr. Grimsby looks unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRIMSBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We just adore your books.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GRIMSBY
dialogues.text: No, I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRIMSBY
dialogues.text: Well, I love them.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GRIMSBY
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You just like a good cry. Dickens gives him a strained smile.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What is it you particularly object to in my books?

dialogues.speaker: MR. GRIMSBY
dialogues.text: Pickpockets, streetwalkers, charity boys. Those people don’t belong in books.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Those people? You mean, the poor? They continue outside the building where Dickens indicate a knot of BARE-FOOT URCHINS, watching from the shadows. Grimsby straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GRIMSBY
dialogues.text: Look here, Mr. Dickens. I’m a self- made man. I pulled myself up by my own bootstraps, never asked for anything from anyone that I wasn’t willing to pay for. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 21 23

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No help from anyone?

dialogues.speaker: MR. GRIMSBY
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRIMSBY
dialogues.text: Well, Papa did give us a very small cotton mill for our wedding. Mr. Grimsby ignores this, whilst shoeing away a poor urch begging for money.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What would you suggest we do about “those people”?

dialogues.speaker: MR. GRIMSBY
dialogues.text: Are there no workhouses?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Do you know that many people had rather die than go there?

dialogues.speaker: MR. GRIMSBY
dialogues.text: Then they had better do it, and reduce the surplus population. Dickens struggles to control his temper.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Will you excuse me? I have a -- I must-- good evening. He strides off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens strides angrily through the chaotic, noisy street London, past WAITERS thrusting handbills into the hands o passersby, CABBIES soliciting fares, a BALLAD SINGER croa out a tune, a barefooted CROSSING SWEEPER leaping into th street to clear away the manure. A TOOTHLESS MAN in a long cloak approaches emerges out of crowd and flashes Dickens a lop-sided grin.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTHLESS MAN
dialogues.text: Care to buy? Hard workers. Suitable for factory work or chimney sweeping. Moving aside his cloak he reveals two CHILDREN, a boy and girl, pale and emaciated, clinging to his legs. Dickens r back in shock. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 22 24

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Let them go! Let them go, or I’1l have the police after you. The man turns and runs, the children in tow. Dickens trie give chase across the street, but is nearly knocked over large cart drawn by four horses. On the side the words ar written: “Warren’s Blacking: The Pride of Mankind”. Dickens freezes. He looks around. The toothless man and h children are gone. Hearing FOOTSTEPS, he gives chase down darkened alleyway. Faster he goes, left, right, until he completely disorientated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning a corner, Dickens finds himself in the graveyard church and collapses under a tree, exhausted. He closes h eyes.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I lift up mine eyes unto the hills From whence cometh my help My help cometh even from the Lord Who hath made heaven and earth-- A gravelly voice cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: -- All right. I’m not paying you by the hour. Skip to the end. Dickens opens his eyes. In the glow of a lantern, a grave side burial is taking place, attended only by a red-nosed CLERIC in a threadbare black coat, and a LONE MOURNER in black silk hat, and two stalwart GRAVE-DIGGERS.

dialogues.speaker: CLERIC
dialogues.text: (rapidly) Rest eternal grant to him, O Lord: And let light perpetual shine upon him. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: LONE MOURNER
dialogues.text: Amen. The Lone Mourner presses a coin into the clergyman’s hand strides away, clearly anxious to be gone. The Grave-diggers shuffle towards the grave, spades in ha Grave Digger #1 points towards the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: GRAVE DIGGER
dialogues.text: Shame, innit? All that money and no- one to mourn him. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 23 24 25

dialogues.speaker: GRAVE DIGGER
dialogues.text: -- except Old Scratch there. He nods towards the departing Lone Mourner.

dialogues.speaker: GRAVE DIGGER
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: GRAVE DIGGER
dialogues.text: His business partner. The meanest cur on two legs, so they say. Dickens shrinks against the wall as the Lone Mourner pass him, shooting him a look of pure malice.

dialogues.speaker: LONE MOURNER
dialogues.text: Humbug. Dickens recoils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dicken returns home, in a state of agitation, muttering t himself.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Old Scratch... all that money... shame... He reaches for the doorknocker when suddenly the door fli open. Dickens reacts as the knocker comes away in his han

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FISK
dialogues.text: Good evening, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Indeed, Mrs. Fisk. He hands her his hat, and heads for the stairs, holds on the knocker, not quite sure what to do with it, past the dining room where the whole family sits waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Charles? Dickens is oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Humbug!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens scribbles furiously, talking to himself, like a m possessed. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 25 26

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s about a businessman. Or a factory owner. A miser. His partner dies. But he doesn’t shed a tear. Thinks only of the money. And on Christmas Eve—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens paces, flushed with excitement, referring to his hastily scrawled notes.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: -—on Christmas Eve— he meets some kind of, of, of, I don’t know- He gestures with his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: —supernatural guides— or, spirits possibly- who in the course of one night, teach him what a miserable, loathsome, selfish toad he is. A short book. Short and sharp. A hammerblow to the heart of this smug, self-satisfied age. Forster and the publishers nod their heads with enthusias though it is clear they don’t follow.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's a comedy. Forster breathes out, with relief.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Ah-ha! Hall Brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Does it have a title?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s called, A Christmas Ghost Story... No, uh— A Christmas— Song. Ballad. Something like that. Chapman clears his throat, glances at Hall.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Intriguing. Really.... Er. One Question— Why Christmas? The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 27 Dickens’s mouth twitches dangerously.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Why not? Hall leaps into the fray.

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: Well, Christmas: Not what it Used to Be, what? He chortles at his own joke.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: I mean to say, Does Anyone Still Celebrate It? Other than our Clerk? Who Never misses an Opportunity to Take a Day off with Pay!

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: Indeed! Ha, ha. More or less an Excuse for Picking a Man's Pocket every Twenty-fifth of December! Dickens stares at them. Hall shifts uncomfortably. An awk silence.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: What We Mean to Say, Mr. Dickens, is, Not Much Market for “Christmas Books”... .What? Dickens tries to control his rising temper. Dickens It is a Christmas book because Christmas is— or ought to be— the one time of the year when men and women open their shut-up hearts, and think of the people below them as if they really were fellow- passengers to the grave, and not another race of creatures altogether. Hall nods, vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Dickens. We are Already Halfway Through October. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 26 28

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even if you Had already Written it, we couldn’t Possibly Get it Illustrated, Typeset, Printed and Bound, Advertised and Distributed to Shops in only Six Weeks. Dickens voice is calm, but his eyes blaze.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I see. Well, gentlemen. Thank you for your opinion. And with that, he rips up the cheque Forster had given hi and sweeps out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Dickens!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens hastens down the street. Forster catches him by t sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: —the scaly-headed vultures— money grubbing, scum-sucking—

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Charles.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I'll do it myself.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I will pay for it, all of it, including the illustrations, and distribute myself.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Charles. This is madness. Think of your finances! Let’s go back and renegotiate. No shame in it. It’s just business. Why throw everything over for a-a- minor holiday? Dickens regards him coldly.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: My mind is made up, John. I've never felt so strongly about anything in my life. You can help me, or not. As you wish. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 27 28 29 29 Dickens storms off, heading straight for a nearby Tailors Shop.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Where are you off to?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: To raise some capital.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (off his look) One thing I’ve learned from my father: people will believe anything if you’re properly dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the steam from the engines, a NATTILY-DRESSED MAN helps his WIFE down from the train. We can’t quite make o his features at first. Then he turns and we see that it i MR. DICKENS SR., older than before but still as ebullient

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Nothing like the air of the metropolis to put colour in your cheeks, eh mother? Mrs. Dickens inhales deeply. INT. HADDOCK’S OFFICE - DAY 29 Forster and Dickens, in his new clothes, perch on uncomfortable chairs in the office of his solicitor. Dickens’s eyes dart around the room: at the PAPERS staine with coffee, GLASSES WITH MOLD halfway up the side. A SAF wound round and about with heavy chains. The door flies open and THOMAS HADDOCK, appears, in a fad coat over a threadbare waistcoat.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Mr. Dickens. Mr. Forster. How do you?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Very well, thank you, Mr. Haddock.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Mittens. Bad boy. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 30 He picks an evil-looking cat off his chair and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now. How can I be of service?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Well, sir, it’s about the loan--

dialogues.speaker: MR. HADDOCK
dialogues.text: - come to think of it, there was something I wanted to tell you. What was it? Haddock gets up and starts to rifle through some DOG-EARE FILES on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: It was rather good news, as I recall-- Haddock finds a plate of biscuits under one of the files and offers them to Forster.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Thank you. Ow! The cat has leapt onto his lap.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Mittens! You rascal... What was I--

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You said you had good news. About the lawsuit?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Lawsuit?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Copyright infringement.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Oliver Twisted. “As Re-originated from the Original.” Haddock has found the file.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Oh, yes! Here it is. Good news indeed. We won. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 31

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: The fine was set at twenty-two hundred pounds. Dickens nearly cries with relief.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Twenty-two hundred— Oh, Haddock. You can’t think how relieved I am. The pirates are beaten—

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: The bad news is the defendants have no money. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Bankrupt... Disappointing, I know... Of course, we could have them arrested. Throw them in the debtor’s prison. Dickens shakes his head, repulsed.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No. No. No.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: As you wish. Meanwhile, if you would be so good. Haddock unlocks a METAL CASE wrapped round with CHAINS an takes out a paper, stamped “Payment on Demand”.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here's my bill. No rush. Next week will be fine. Haddock dips his biscuit in his tea, placidly. Dickens attempts to stifle his anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: The thing is, Haddock... He glances at Forster. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 32

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m waiting for a big royalty cheque from America. A trifling sum what was it, 400 pounds, Forster? Forster nearly chokes on his biscuit.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Mm? Something like that. The solicitor listens attentively.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Tell you what... why don’t we defer this bill until, say January. And, while we're at it, perhaps you might add a little more to it. I’1l make it worth your while.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: More? You mean, borrow more?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Not much— perhaps 300 pounds? Until— until, January. Forster reaches for the tea. The solicitor thinks. Dicken looks pale, wipes his brow.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: I’m sure we can work something out. At, say, twenty-five percent? Forster can’t contain himself.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: God’s teeth! The cat leaps off Forster’s lap with a piteous MEOW. Dick is not well. Ashen.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: However, I will require the money to be repaid at the end of January without fail.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Of course. Forster here will sort out the details with you. Dickens walks carefully from the room, as if he might fai The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 30 31 33 EXT. HADDOCK’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS 30 Dickens hastens down the street, and turns the corner. He leans up against the wall, eyes closed, sweating.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Charles? Dickens opens his eyes to find FORSTER looking at him closely. He claps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charles? Are you all right? Dickens straightens up, shrugging off the moment.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: A kidney spasm. That’s all. He stalks off.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder) Find me an illustrator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dickens Senior is showing a PAWNBROKER a book as his looks on.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Best quality, sir. Al condition.... and look — He opens the cover.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Inscribed by the author. The pawnbroker peers at the handwritten inscription.

dialogues.speaker: PAWNBROKER
dialogues.text: To Papa. Love, Charles. The pawnbroker examines Dickens Senior skeptically. PAWNBROKER (CONT’D) Five bob.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hallo old girl. Hallo old girl. Mr. Dickens looks up to see a CAGED CROW, walking up and on his perch. Mr. Dickens’s face lights up. He turns back the pawnbroker. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 32 33 34 35 34

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Perhaps we might strike a bargain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the study, a trio of servants and Tara are giggli as they listen to the master making strange noises.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Oh but he was a tight-fisted hand at the grindstone, old— ... Scratch? Scrounger?...

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: - a covetous old sinner! ... old — whatshisname! He throws his pen down in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ....Screwpull.... Scrabbly... scr—rrrr—aahhh— chh...aahhh They push Tara forward.

dialogues.speaker: SERVANT
dialogues.text: Go on. He won’t bite. Tara knocks softly on the door, and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tara enters. Dickens is nowhere to be seen. She tiptoes o to the fire. Suddenly, she hears—

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr.... Scrimple! She squeals with terror. Dickens sits up from the couch w he has been lying and takes the handkerchief off his face

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You, what are you doing in here?

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: I've just come to see to the fire, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I’m not to be interrupted under any circumstances. Do you hear? The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 35

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon, sir. It won't happen again. Tara turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Wait. What’s that in your pocket? Tara’s takes out a Penny Dreadful magazine and reluctantl hands it over to Dickens. Dickens examines the cover: a winged vampire with bloody teeth.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Varney the Vampire: The Feast of Blood.” Any good?

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, sir. Thrilling. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Where did you learn to read?

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: My mum taught me. But then she died. So, I had to go to the Grubber. Dickens recoils.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: The Workhouse?

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: You won’t tell Mrs. Fisk, will you? She'd think I was shirking.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: It will be our secret. Dickens plucks a book off the shelf: The Arabian Nights.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In fact, I'll make you a trade. Varney the Vampire for... Aladdin and his Magic Lamp. She takes the book in her hands with awe.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Oh. My. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 36

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Read it and tell me what you think.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. She hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: TARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who is Scrimple?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Scrimple?

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: When I came in... You was saying—

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: It’s just a name. In a story I’m concocting. You get the name right and then— if you’re lucky — the character will appear. Tara eyes dart around the room.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s not here yet. He smiles. Then is struck by a thought. He starts to pace oblivious to her.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Scrantish? Tara tiptoes out, unobserved.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: S—c—rarmer—... S—c—r—ungge. No! Come on, come on, you old sinner. He closes his eyes, conjuring up the image of the Lone Mourner in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: A sudden gust of wind makes the fire leap up, the papers around the room.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shut the window! Do you think I am made of money? Dickens jumps. Behind him, SCROOGE, dressed as the Lone Mourner. Dickens is awe-struck. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 37

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Mr. Scrooge. How delightful to meet you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I can’t say the same.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Come now, Mr. Scrooge. Don’t be standoffish. We ought to be friends.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Don’t have friends. Don’t need ‘em. Dickens laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Naturally.... I know. Let’s play a game.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: I don’t like games.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Humour me... What do you think of when I say the word “Darkness”.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Cheap.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Love.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: A Swindle.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Money.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Security.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Children.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Nuisances.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Workhouse.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Useful. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 36 38

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Christmas. A strange look passes over Scrooge’s face.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: That’s right. Dickens leans in, pen at the ready. They both jump at the sound of a piercing SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FISK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Help! Help! Get it away! Dickens throws open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens thunders down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What is going on? He sees Miss Fisk cowering in a corner, as a large RAVEN makes a dive at her head.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FISK
dialogues.text: Get it away! The filthy thing! The children laugh and clap their hands as Mr. Dickens wa a cage at the bird.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Come on now, Grip. Back in your cage, old chap.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Father?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Charles! Good day!

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: I was in the neighbourhood. Thought I'd drop by with a present for the children.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: His name is Grip! He talks! The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 37 39 Grip is on a ledge, marching back and forth in agitation.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Can we keep him?

dialogues.speaker: GRIP
dialogues.text: Halloa, old girl. Halloa old girl. Mrs. Fisk clutches the edge of the bannister.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FISK
dialogues.text: It’s bad luck. A bird in the house. It means death. Dickens motions for his father to move into the parlour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens turns to address his father.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What are you doing back in London?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: My dear Charles. I will not disguise from you, that this is not the ardor with which a loving father might be expected—

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You are supposed to be in Devon.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Ha, banishment! Be merciful, say ‘death;' For exile hath more terror in his look—'

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: We had an agreement. I bought you a house. Gave you an allowance. Mr. Dickens looks sheepish.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: And you know how very grateful I am. As for me, I’m happy wherever the weather. But your Mother— is of a more delicate sensibility. The sight of cows causes her actual physical pain.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Father— The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 40

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: And then you see, I need to do some research in the London Library. Dickens is skeptical of this.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Research?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: I have a commission from the Spectator. To write a feature on the Bank Charter Act. The editor was greatly impressed by my series on Marine Insurance. Kate and Mrs. Dickens appear in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Good for you, Father. And I hope you and Mother will stay here with us. She shoots a look at Dickens.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The children and I will enjoy having some company in the evening. Mr. Dickens glances at his son, apprehensively.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (relenting) The Spectator. Most impressive.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Thank you my boy... (dropping his voice) Er. You couldn’t perhaps lend me a tenner? The fellow took my last farthing for the cage. Suddenly there is an ominous CRASH in the hallway. They r to see Grip, perched on the new chandelier, causing bits pieces to fall to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ll see that’s all cleaned up. The children surround Mr. Dickens, delighted, as Dickens holds his tongue and heads back upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens paces, gripping his hair in frustration.  The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Gah! “This is not the ardor, with which a loving father-” January 8, 2016 41 He throws himself down on the couch. He looks up and sees Scrooge.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Humbug.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Christmas. Dickens sits up.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: What is it but an excuse for picking a man’s pocket every twenty- fifth of December?... Dickens jumps up and runs to his desk and rapidly goes through his pre-writing ritual.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes, yes! Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: .+-a time for paying bills without money.... Dickens starts to write, furiously.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .+.a time for finding yourself a year older and not an hour richer.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Excellent.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: If I could work my will, every idiot who goes about with “Merry Christmas” on his lips, should be boiled with his own pudding and buried with a stake of holly through his heart. He should. Dickens laughs out loud. He looks at Scrooge, admiringly. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 42

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Scrooge. You and I are going to do great things together. Dickens starts scratching away, while Scrooge peers over shoulder, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, but he was a tight-fisted hand at the grindstone, Scrooge. A squeezing, wrenching, grasping, scraping, clutching, covetous old sinner! Hard and sharp as flint, from which no steel had ever struck out generous fire; secret, and self- contained and solitary as an oyster. Dickens glances over his shoulder. Scrooge immediately rearranges his features into a scowl. There is a KNOCK at the door.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Charles? Scrooge disappears. Mr. Dickens pokes his head in, smilin

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hard at work? Dickens grits his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What can I help you with, Father?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: I wondered if we might have an extra candlestick for our room?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Of course. He hands him a candlestick. Mr. Dickens eyes a box on the mantelpiece.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Oooo. Are those cigars? Mr. Dickens advances into the room.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I must confess, I have acquired an irrepressible habit of smoking whilst I write. Shameful, I know. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 43 He pockets the box.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well. I won’t detain you. He tiptoes out. Dickens picks up the doorknocker from the front door, now sat on his desk, and raps on it a few tim angrily. Scrooge immediately reappears, a look of alarm o his face.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Don’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: He’ll think he’s being summoned-- Suddenly, the air is filled with a terrible clanking soun as of chains being dragged up the stairs and the hallway. Scrooge looks terrified.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Too late.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Who is it? Scrooge is too terrified to speak. Dickens picks up his b of names, rapidly flipping through the list.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Uh...Bunsby. Clennam. Heep...Hexam.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Magwitch?... Marley... The lights in the room dim one by one. Suddenly, the door flies open and the ghost of JACOB MARLEY (bearing a stron resemblance to his solicitor, Haddock), covered in chains padlocks, cash-boxes and steel purses, appears. Scrooge attempts a smile.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Jacob? Is that you? Dickens looks at Scrooge.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You know him? The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: My business partner. Last I saw him, he was dead as a doornail. The ghost gives out a dreadful howl.

dialogues.speaker: MARLEY
dialogues.text: Business! Mankind was my business! The common welfare was my business; charity, mercy, forbearance, and benevolence, were, all, my business. But I did none of these.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: He was never one for a straight answer. The ghost gives another howl.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Come in, I pray you. 44 Marley clanks into the room, dragging his chains.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are in chains. Tell me why.

dialogues.speaker: MARLEY
dialogues.text: I wear the chain I forged in life. I made it link by link, and yard by yard. I girded it on of my own free will, and of my own free will I wore it.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: MARLEY
dialogues.text: Is its pattern strange to you? Dickens starts to write.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: «+.. Strange to you....

dialogues.speaker: MARLEY
dialogues.text: Or would you know the weight and length of the strong coil you bear yourself? Dickens looks up. Marley is staring straight at takes a careful step towards Marley.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You mean him, surely. him. Dickens The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 39 45 Marley leans towards him, confidentially. He walks around Dickens, circling him with a loose chain.

dialogues.speaker: MARLEY
dialogues.text: Chains man, all around you. Past... and present... and what is to come. Dickens stares at him, his mind racing. And with that, Ma pulls the loose chain tight around Dickens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children crowd around the Christmas table. Mr. Dicken the head, in a richly patterned waistcoat. A cheer goes up as Mrs. Dickens, sets a large turkey down the table. Mr. Dickens holds up his hands for silence. He intones.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Hail to thee blithe turkey. Whose exquisite odours now perfume the circumambient air. So let this day be fragrant with the love we bear each other. And may God bless us everyone. He winks at YOUNG CHARLES, who stares up at him with adoration.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARLES
dialogues.text: +...every one. Suddenly, the door flies open. A BAILIFF fills the door frame, accompanied by two burly Deputies.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Mr. John Dickens?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: That is my name.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: What is the meaning of this termagant breach of our Yuletide feast?

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Eh? The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 40 4l 46

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: What is the matter?

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: The matter is a debt of some forty pounds and ten shillings. Fourteen months in arrears. The bailiff holds out a set of handcuffs.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you please. The deputies enter the room, and start loading household goods onto a cart, furniture, silverware, books, anything they can get their hands on.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Gentlemen! Please! This is all a misunderstanding. A circumstance of great moment to me is to be decided in the ensuing term — Young Charles bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARLES
dialogues.text: Tell them to stop. Tell them to stop! A handcuffed Mr. Dickens is helpless to comfort him. As h struggles to reach Charles, he knocks the magic lantern a it falls, shattering on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens wakes with a start. He is lying on the couch. He looks around. The room is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens marches along the foot path, with Forster struggl to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What about Leech? For the illustrations.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Leech? He’s so prickly. And by no means the cheapest—

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I don’t want the cheapest-— The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 47

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: -Charles. For God’s sake, slow down. You move at railway speed. Dickens slows down slightly.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I want the best.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: It’s going well then?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: The book.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Brilliant. Best thing I’ve ever done.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: So you’re--

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I have eleven pages.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: - Eleven?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: If it weren’t for the constant interruptions - you know my father’s staying with us?

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Indeed. He could not have come at a worse time- Forster is distracted by the sight of a pretty young woma (CHARLOTTE WIGMORE, age 25) walking by with a CHAPERONE.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Ooh! Charlotte’s face lights up at the sight of Forster. Her companion turns her around to walk the other way.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Who was that? The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 48

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: My fiancee. I told you--

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Fiancee?

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: She's a canny lass, is she not?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Indeed, most amiable.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Amiable? Why man, she’s an angel, a sylph, a- I don’t know what. Suddenly Forster bursts into tears. Dickens stares at him perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Whatever is the matter?

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Charlotte and I — have come to a parting of the ways.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I thought you said you were engaged—

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Were. Her father had no intention for her to marry the son of a Gateshead butcher. Dickens tries to think what to say.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Perhaps its for the best. The life matrimonial... it’s not for everyone, old stick. Forster manfully masters his emotions.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: No doubt. No doubt. Forster blows his nose. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 42 49

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So... Leech?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: That’s the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens and Forster visit LEECH, an eccentric-looking man with hair like a rooster. Forster studies the framed cart on the wall as Dickens describes his vision to Leech.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Four wood cuts and four etchings. The cover in red. Hand-coloured. The title in rustic writing. The end papers to be green and all three edges to be gilded.

dialogues.speaker: LEECH
dialogues.text: Gilded? That will cost you.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: It must be exquisite. That’s why we came to you.

dialogues.speaker: LEECH
dialogues.text: You’1l have to sell every copy to make your money back.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: That is my intention, Mr. Leech. Leech purses his lips together.

dialogues.speaker: LEECH
dialogues.text: Have you brought the manuscript?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I'll have something for you ina week.

dialogues.speaker: LEECH
dialogues.text: A week? That leaves only four weeks to do the illustrations and get it to the printers in time for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Can you do it?

dialogues.speaker: LEECH
dialogues.text: Mr. Dickens. I am not a hired hand. I am an artist. What you are asking is impossible. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 43 44 45 50

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Impossible for an ordinary man, yes. But you are no ordinary man, Mr. Leech. You are a genius. Leech draws himself up like a poker.

dialogues.speaker: LEECH
dialogues.text: Fifty pounds. Paid in advance. Plus more for the plates. Dickens hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Done. Forster passes his hand over his face as Dickens heads fo the door.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Charles-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forster confronts Dickens on the street outside Leech’s studio.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Look, Charles, I don’t mean to be the voice of doom but before we lay out money for illustrations, we should consider what happens if you don’t finish on time.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I will finish on time. Forster doesn’t have the heart to pursue it.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens arrives home. The door is open. A workman stands it, perplexed by the missing door knocker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens steps in. Mrs. Fisk takes his hat.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Thank you— Signor Mazzini is fixing the chandelier. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 46 51

dialogues.speaker: SIGNOR MAZZINI
dialogues.text: Mr. Dickens. I fix. See?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes. Grazie, Mr. Mazzini.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNOR MAZZINI
dialogues.text: Is no problem. No problem! Only twelve guineas extra! There is a sound of LAUGHTER in the parlour above. Dicken turns to Mrs. Fisk.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I thought my father was off to the British library.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FISK
dialogues.text: It’s your sister, sir. Come from Manchester with her little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens’ sister FANNY (mid-thirties, pretty but faded) is the floor, with her young son, HENRY JR, and all the Dick children, playing with a toy theatre. Henry’s father, the REVEREND HENRY BURNETT looks on, beaming.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Fanny! Fanny glances up.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Charlie! She jumps up to embrace her brother.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Henry. How are you? Dickens shakes the Reverend Henry’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND HENRY
dialogues.text: Very well, grace be to God. Dickens smiles at his nephew on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Master Henry. I hardly recognize you. How old are you now? Henry struggles to his feet, with the help of a crutch. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 52

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HENRY
dialogues.text: Nine, if you please sir. He coughs, violently.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Nine. Is it possible? Tara enters, a little shyly.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. The children’s tea is ready in the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND HENRY
dialogues.text: Come on, then young ‘un. The Reverend puts Young Henry on his shoulders, and follo Tara and the other children out the door and down the sta Fanny watches them go.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: There goes my heart.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What did the doctor say?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: He says we have to wait and see.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Fanny. Won’t you let me help?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: We'll manage.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: At least until Henry gets a new position?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Something will turn up. I’m sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You sound like father. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: How is the old reprobate? Dickens adopts their father’s tone of voice.  The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions 47

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: “This morning I had twenty-five shillings in my hand and now... He holds out his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Observe the vacancy.” They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: He means no harm.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: It’s not enough. He bobs along like a cork on the surface of life, no thought for the future-- Fanny puts her hand on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Charlie. Let it go, can’t you?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Abaft, you scurvy pirates! January 8, 2016 53 Dickens and Fanny crack open the door. Mr. Dickens, has j arrived home, Young Henry at his side. The children are crowded around him, rummaging in his pockets for gifts as shouts, uproariously.

dialogues.speaker: MR DICKENS
dialogues.text: Brail up your capstan-bar! Sheepshank your mizzen! Full speed ahead! She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: For all his faults, you won't find a kinder man. Dickens sighs.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: How long he is growing up to be one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 Dickens wakes up with a start. Scrooge is standing over h with a candle.  Yellow Revisions January 8, 2016 54 The Man Who Invented Christmas

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (whispers) Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: You'd better come and see who’s turned up. Beside him, in bed, Kate stirs.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Charles? Dickens puts his finger to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Just a touch of indigestion... Go back to sleep. Dickens and Scrooge creep out. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 48 55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens and Scrooge stare at a ghostly figure (looking a deal like Tara), dressed in white, wearing a wreath on he head. She stands by the window where the muslin curtains float eerily around her in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Tell him who you are.

dialogues.speaker: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PAST
dialogues.text: I am the Ghost of Christmas Past. The Ghost gestures towards the window. GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PAST (CONT’D) Follow.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: It's awfully late and I’m not quite dressed.

dialogues.speaker: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PAST
dialogues.text: Follow. Scrooge draws back.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Not bloody likely.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Mucking around in the past? What’s the point?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You might learn something.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: I already know everything I need to know. (to the Ghost) Take him, why don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: If you’re so keen. The ghost turns her gaze to Dickens. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: It’s not about me.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: You’re the author aren’t you? Dickens looks at the ghost, fearful. He doesn’t move. The Ghost turns to look at the slightly ajar window, which no SLAMS wide open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Charles holds his father’s hand tightly, through th bars of a bailiff’s van, trying to keep from crying. The of the family are huddled together behind his father in t van.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Don’t cry, Charlie. We’ll be back for you before you know it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARLES
dialogues.text: But why can’t I stay with you?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: You're a big boy now, Charlie. You need to help out. You’ll see. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 50 56

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It will be an adventure. You’1ll hardly think of us at all. Behind him, the bailiff climbs on board the van.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Time to go. Young Charles starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Now, sir, enough of that. Stand up tall. Blood of iron, heart of ice. The van starts to move off. Young Charles lets go of his father’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shouting back) Remember: you are the son of John Dickens. A Gentleman. You be sure and tell them that! The van disappears around the corner. The boy turns and l with dread at the old, tumbledown building, beneath the s WARRENS BLACKING: “The Pride of Mankind”. A door opens spilling some light.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARLES
dialogues.text: (trying to gather strength) Blood of iron, heart of ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens is in bed, tossing in his sleep. Kate comes in, dressed for the day. Dickens awakes with a start.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Good morning. She bustles about the room.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What? Oh. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You were tossing and turning all night, you know.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Bad dreams.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What about? The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 51 57 He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Shadows. Nothing more.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: A little daylight will cure you. She throws open the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. MARKET
dialogues.text: A theatre curtain is pulled aside to reveal a puppet show performing to a watching crowd in the COVERED market. All bustle and colour. Dickens wanders amongst the stalls overflowing with brigh coloured goods, tin pans, second-hand clothes, baskets of chestnuts, pears and apples, piles of filberts. Suddenly, a figure is there, tugging on his sleeve. It’s Scrooge.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: I trust we’ll have no more of that. Dickens is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: of --?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: The past. A lot of nonsense. Onward. Scrooge flinches as a couple of CHILDREN run screaming by them.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Were you never a child, Mr. Scrooge?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: I don’t recall. Come on, we’re wasting time. We should be working.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I am working.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Here?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I'm gathering inspiration. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 58

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Gathering... what?? Dickens gestures.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What do you see? When you look around?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: A market.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What else? He points to various people in the market: A PIEMAN with arms laden with pie cans, yelling:

dialogues.speaker: PIEMAN
dialogues.text: Pies all’ot! Eel, beef, or mutton pies! Penny Pies, all’ ot!
