dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Buyers and sellers.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What else? A Cockney SCAM ARTIST, doing a patter.

dialogues.speaker: SCAM ARTIST
dialogues.text: ...-Three thimbles and one little pea- with a one, two, three, and a two, three, one, catch him who can, look on, keep your eyes open and niver say die!

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Thieves and ruffians. As they step out from the “souk” into the open air street market, He points to A YOUNG COUPLE, lost in admiration o each other. A NEWSAGENT, calling out:

dialogues.speaker: NEWSAGENT
dialogues.text: Times, gen’l’mn, Times! Highly Interesting murder, gen’1‘mn, A FIDDLER, plays a tune and a BUTCHER calls out.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Clear away! Clear away, lads! The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 59 He tosses the fiddler a coin, catches up his WIFE and sta to dance. Dickens laughs with pleasure, then looks at Scrooge, who shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Life, Mr. Scrooge! London! The great theatre of the world! It’s all here!

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Humbug.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You say that a lot.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: I’m aman of facts and calculations. Realities, not fancy... Not-- not-- what the devil is that?-- Dickens and Scrooge stare at a strange sight: a PAPIER MA BOTTLE is toddling along the street. When the bottle reac Dickens, a hand pops out of it, and thrusts a flyer in hi hand: an advertisement for Warren’s Blacking. Dickens is frozen for a moment, unnerved. He takes off in other direction.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Must go.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder) Back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family are at the dinner table waiting to eat. Mr. Dickens entertains the children, making them giggle.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Papa... potatoes... poultry... and prunes... are all very good words for the lips. At the other end of the table, Mrs. Dickens reminisces fo Kate’s benefit. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DICKENS
dialogues.text: And oh, the parties.... We used to keep such hours! Balls, dinners— champagne— Mr. Dickens ties his napkin around his head, winks at the children. The children giggle. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 60

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Well, it looks as if Charles won’t be joining us this evening. Again. We may as well begin. Mr. Dickens has already begun.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: First rate capon, Mrs. Fisk.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FISK
dialogues.text: Thank you sir. I’1l let the cook know.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DICKENS
dialogues.text: .-.-and the chairs had turned legs with green chintz squabs to match the curtains. At that moment, Dickens appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What story is that, Mother? Mrs. Dickens reddens.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DICKENS
dialogues.text: I was only telling Kate about the dining room set we used to have. Rosewood. In the most approved taste.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: You mean, the one we pawned? An awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Charles. You are a satirical monster. Kate is bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Is that a joke, dear?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Not a very amusing one. Mrs. Dickens examines her hands, mortified. An awkward silence. Dickens turns a cold eye on his father.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that a new waistcoat father? The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 53 61

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Eh? What? Oh, yes. Persian crimson. It is a little more expensive, but I've always said, people will believe anything if you’re properly dressed. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Kate. Will you ask Tara to bring up a tray with something on it?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I‘ll bring it up.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No! I need Tara to do it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: That's the spirit my boy. Procrastination is the thief of time, eh Charles. Collar him! Dickens looks at him, but decides not to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FISK
dialogues.text: I‘ll get her sir. Tara! Mr. Dickens, unperturbed, digs into his food.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: We must never disturb the poet when the divine frenzy is upon him. I myself have suffered the same delirium. Often to the detriment of my health, as you know, my love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens is talking to himself in the mirror, like a mad m

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Know the place! Was I apprenticed here? Why it’s old Fezziwig! Behind him, in the room, the FEZZIWIGS appear (the genial BUTCHER and his WIFE from the market). They start to danc

dialogues.speaker: FEZZIWIG
dialogues.text: Clear away, lads! Clear away! It’s Friday night! There is a knock on the door. The Fezziwigs freeze. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 54 55 56 62

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: TARA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s Tara, sir. With your dinner. Dickens throws open the door.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Tara. Come in. Come in. He takes the tray from her.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sit. I want to read you something.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t think Mrs. Fisk—

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Skittleshins to Mrs. Fisk. Sit. Please. She does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate sits alone and bored. Another evening without the company of her husband. She looks at the ceiling. The stu above her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens is reading to Tara from the manuscript. She smile lost in her imagination.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: .-. in easy state upon this couch, there sat a jolly giant, who bore a glowing torch and held it up to shed its light on Scrooge as he came peeping round the corner.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: The second ghost! The lights in the room slowly brighten, revealing the GHO OF CHRISTMAS PRESENT (bearing a strong resemblance to For in a beard), seated high up on a throne, amidst a cornuco of apples and oranges and pears, chestnuts, mistletoe and holly. Around him in a circle, various other CHARACTERS f the book, stare up in rapt attention. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 63 The Ghost laughs as he sees Scrooge approach, shielding h eyes from the bright light.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Who are you? The ghost laughs.

dialogues.speaker: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PRESENT
dialogues.text: I am the Ghost of Christmas present. Come closer man and know me better. Scrooge fearfully climbs the library steps.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but -- why all this- produce? The Ghost laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PRESENT
dialogues.text: These are the gifts of abundance, of good will and generosity.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PRESENT
dialogues.text: Of course you wouldn’t understand much about that, would you? Unlike these good people. The Ghost of Christmas Present points towards the hearth, where the CRATCHIT FAMILY including BOB (looking a good d like Henry Burnett Sr.), and TINY TIM (a paler, more frag version of Henry) are seated round a table, staring joyfu at a very modest Christmas dinner of mashed potatoes, app sauce, gravy, and a very small roasted goose.

dialogues.speaker: CRATCHIT
dialogues.text: My dear Mrs. Cratchit. You have outdone yourself this year. Mrs. Cratchit beams, and looks around at her children.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CRATCHIT
dialogues.text: Everyone pitched in. Even Tim. Tim points to the mismatched cups and plates.

dialogues.speaker: TINY TIM
dialogues.text: I set the table! Cratchit lifts his glass. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 64

dialogues.speaker: CRATCHIT
dialogues.text: A Merry Christmas to us all, my dears. And may God bless us.

dialogues.speaker: TINY TIM
dialogues.text: God bless us every one! Tiny Tim’s little body is racked with coughs. Cratchit pi him up in his arms. Scrooge stares at Tiny Tim, moved.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: I didn’t know Cratchit had a crippled son.

dialogues.speaker: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PRESENT
dialogues.text: Didn't you ever think to ask?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: He’s my clerk. I don’t pay him to tell me about his personal life.

dialogues.speaker: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PRESENT
dialogues.text: You hardly pay him at all.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Fifteen shillings a week.

dialogues.speaker: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PRESENT
dialogues.text: For a man with a family? Not too mention a sick child.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: That is the market rate. The ghost bristles.

dialogues.speaker: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PRESENT
dialogues.text: Do you really believe that every inch of existence is a bargain across the counter?

dialogues.speaker: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PRESENT
dialogues.text: Observe this family. They don’t have much, and yet they’re happy, grateful and contented with the time. Whereas you are miserable and content with nothing. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 65

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: I never heard such folly. A clock in the room strikes the hour.

dialogues.speaker: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PRESENT
dialogues.text: Heed well what I have said. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: No. Wait-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Intermission. The characters spontaneously applaud as Scrooge and the G take a bow.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FEZZIWIG
dialogues.text: Thrilling performance.

dialogues.speaker: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS PRESENT
dialogues.text: That’s very kind.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FEZZIWIG
dialogues.text: Where did you train? A clock in the room strikes the hour. The lights start returning to normal. The characters disappear. Dickens turns over the last page of the manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: And that’s as far as I’ve got. Tara stirs herself, like one awaking from a sleep.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tara? The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January She nods, 66 still half in a dream, then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: How do you do that, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What, Tara?

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Make a world, come alive.... I could almost see and hear them people. She drifts out the door.

dialogues.speaker: TARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Especially that Tiny Tim. The poor mite Dickens pleased his writing has affected someone so much, turns to see Scrooge, jolting him out of his reverie.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: A word in your ear. Dickens is wary.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: About?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: The scene. It’s very one-sided-

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: One-sided?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: My character doesn’t get to explain his side of things. I’ve taken the liberty of writing a speech -

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: -- something about the rational self-interest and the natural tendency of free markets--

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No. No. And no. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: 56A
dialogues.text: 57 Scrooge scowls.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: What kind of book is this, anyway? Dickens sweeps out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens and Forster study a sketch that Leech has done.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: No! Too gloomy. The Ghost of Christmas Present should be wonderful. Warm. Jolly.

dialogues.speaker: LEECH
dialogues.text: Jolly.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LEECH
dialogues.text: A jolly ghost.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: That’s it. 67

dialogues.speaker: 56A
dialogues.text: 57 Leech goes to a cabinet and counts out fifty pounds in ca

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: LEECH
dialogues.text: I am returning your money.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: —My dear Mr. Leech—

dialogues.speaker: LEECH
dialogues.text: Find another artist.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: We don’t want another artist.

dialogues.speaker: LEECH
dialogues.text: A jolly Christmas ghost? What does that mean? I can’t draw what I don’t understand! The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 68

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Well, he’s — he’s everything that’s best about Christmas. He’s the soul of kindness and generosity, he’s- He glances at Forster.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Forster.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 58 INT. LEECH’S STUDIO - LATER 58 Forster, dressed in a sheet, open to his navel, and holdi lamp aloft, poses uncomfortably while Dickens applies mak to his cheeks. Leech waits to sketch him. 59 EXT. LONDON/HATCHARD’S - NIGHT 59 Dickens is stopped outside of Hatchard’s. In the store wi a sign advertises “A New Christmas Book by Mr. Dickens. O Now and Avoid Disappointment.” Dickens peers through the window lost in thought. Suddenly, a POSSE of Characters from the book appears beh him, Scrooge amongst them, staring in at the window.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: (to Cratchit) In stores by Christmas? That will be a miracle. The posse sniggers.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Go away.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Three flops in a row. Up to your eyeballs in debt. I’d think you’d be glad of some advice. The POSSE nods in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: All right. I’ve had a few flops, what of it? I’m still young. It’s not as if I-- The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 60 69 Suddenly the surrounding area falls into darkness as the lamps dim one by one. Scrooge turns pale as shadows take the street. Dickens turns to see the POSSE and SCROOGE staring at a dark STATUE across the road. Slowly the statue comes to life, its robes float eerily i the wind, giving form to a terrifying Phantom, its face obscured by a hood. (The GHOST OF CHRISTMAS YET-TO-COME). Dickens and Scrooge exchange fearful looks.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are we in the presence of the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come? The Spirit nods.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: (to Dickens) Why doesn’t he speak?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Shhh. (to Ghost) You are here to show us the shadows of the things that have not happened but will happen, is that so? The Spirit slowly raises a shrouded arm and points down t street, the giant shadow of its finger comes to a stop at small door.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: (whispering to Dickens) Where does it want us to go?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I think I know. With that he heads towards the door, SCROOGE and the POSS following.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: I have a bad feeling about this.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They entered poor Bob Cratchit’s house and found the mother and the children seated round the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cratchit and the children, dressed in black, huddle together by the fire. Tiny Tim is not among them. We see lonely crutch leaning against the fireplace. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 70

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then Bob came in the door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CRATCHIT
dialogues.text: You went today, then Robert? To the cemetery? Cratchit struggles to be cheerful as he enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: CRATCHIT
dialogues.text: Yes, my dear. I wish you could have gone to see how green a place it is. But you’ll see it often. I promised him that I would walk there on a Sunday. He smiles through his tears.

dialogues.speaker: CRATCHIT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My little child. My little, little child! His voice cracks and he covers his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Oh no! The characters freeze. Scrooge shoots a look over his shoulder, TO REVEAL THE SCENE IS TAKING PLACE IN DICKENS

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Rude! Tara has been listening to the story, her eyes wide with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Is Tiny Tim dead?

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Of course he is. Imbecile.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: (gently) He was very ill.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: You can’t save every child in London.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: And the family has no money for a doctor. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 71 Tara is becoming upset.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Then Scrooge must save him. Scrooge is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Me? Dickens looks from one to the other.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: But he wouldn’t-

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: He’s too selfish.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: He can change. There’s good in him somewhere, I know it. Scrooge rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: People don’t change.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: He’s been this way for a long time. I’m not sure he can change.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Of course he can. He’s not a monster.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I don’t - he isn’t -

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Thought this was a ghost story. Not a fairy tale.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: He wouldn’t let Tiny Tim die, Mr. Dickens. He has a heart, doesn’t he? It would be too wicked. Even for him. Dickens stares at them a moment, now plagued with doubt.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the noisy, squalid factory, Young Charles is led b Foreman to a score of pale-faced, miserable-looking CHILD all of them busy pasting labels on bottles or packing the casks.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Boys. This here is Charlie Dickens. And what was it you was just telling me, lad? About your Dad? Young Charles draws himself up proudly.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARLES
dialogues.text: My father is a gentleman. The boys jeer. Young Charles flushes with embarrassment. One of the boys, POLL, calls out.

dialogues.speaker: POLL
dialogues.text: Where is he, then? Dining with the queen? Another boy calls out.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I ‘eard he’s in the stone jug.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Hush, you lot. Where’s your manners? The Foreman addresses him with elaborate politeness.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Master Dickens. Perhaps you would be so good as to join us at work? If you’ve nothing better to do? The Foreman thrusts him down hard onto the work bench. Yo Charles looks around, miserable, at his surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No shirking here. A rat scuttles nearby, to reveal a sheer drop to the gian blacking VATS below. Poll sits down beside him and hisses him. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: POLL
dialogues.text: You're no better than me, cocker. You'd best learn that.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 73

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens sits at his desk. He looks at the clock. It’s the middle of the night. He once again goes through his ritua straightening everything on his desk. He tidies his manuscript, picks up his pen, dips it in in then stares at the paper. There is a racket in the hallway outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: 'Tis now the very witching time of night,

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DICKENS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shhh, dear. Mr. and Mrs. Dickens are in the hallway outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: When churchyards yawn and hell itself breathes out— Scrooge appears.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Shakespeare. Now there’s a man who could write. I doubt he ever had a blockage.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now could I drink hot blood! Dickens grips his hair in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: (egging dickens on) Self-preservation is the first law of nature. That’s just a fact. Dickens throws open the door to find Mr. Dickens, drunken negotiating the stairs with the help of Mrs. Dickens.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DICKENS
dialogues.text: That's right dear. Just a few more steps.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: “Oh, heart lose not thy nature; let not ever the soul of Nero-- Mr. Dickens sees Charles and attempts to regain his postu The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. Good evening, Charles. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January Mrs. 74 Dickens is a little afraid of her son.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DICKENS
dialogues.text: We'll get him straight into bed, Charles, dear. We were up the river to Kew and I think perhaps it was too long a day.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Kew! What about your newspaper article?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Article?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: The one you’re writing on the Bank Charter Act? It’s been over a month. Mr. Dickens shifts, uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Oh, that. As it happens, the editor was not able to— that is to say— due to pecuniary involvements of a complicated nature— he found it necessary to— to cancel the commission.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: So. No newspaper article.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: However, I rejoice to say that I have every hope of something turning up — Dickens sees Scrooge hovering behind him, scowling. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I think it’s time you went back to Devon, Father.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: As soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Of course, dear boy. We shall catch the afternoon train tomorrow. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 75 He stumbles and nearly falls, but is caught by Tara.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (with dignity) Thank you, my dear. Here-- He fumbles in his pocket for a coin.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me give you something for your trouble.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: (confused) Whose grave it that? There’s no name on the headstone.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Why should there be? The man to whom this grave belongs never made himself useful to anyone but himself. No friends. No family. Never felt love, or joy, or took any kind of pleasure in life... It’s time. Mr. Scrooge. We’ve come to the end-- Scrooge unnerved, turns back to Dickens only to see an ea wall where Dickens was stood. Turning again and then again he realizes he is surrounded earth walls. Looking up he sees the blank headstone. He realizes he is now inside the empty grave. Dickens appear above, framed by the blacking factory ceiling. Suddenly the walls of the grave start closing in on Scroo

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Please. - I- don’t want to die like this, alone, unloved, forgotten. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Too late. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 87 88 89 95

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE
dialogues.text: Never too late! Oh, never too late. Please. I’1l change. The grave walls keep closing.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: —- I will honour Christmas in my heart, and try to keep it all the year. I will live in the Past, the Present and the Future. I will not shut out the lessons that they teach. He looks directly at Dickens, imploring him.

dialogues.speaker: SCROOGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give me another chance. I beg you. Let me do some good before I die. The walls stop closing, a beat, then they start opening. Scrooge is delighted, laughing, crying as the walls pull back. He smiles, genuinely transformed. Dickens smiles ba

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: And so we come to the last chapter. Somewhere, a church bell CHIMES twelve o’clock. Dickens l around, shocked to discover that the warehouse is empty a he is all alone. He lets out a sharp breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters taking a deep, steadying breath, then goes over his desk and pulls out a new sheet of paper. He writes: “Stave Five: The End of It.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early morning light filters in through the windows as Dic bends over his writing, his pen SCRATCHING AWAY:

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Scrooge was better than his word. He did it all and infinitely more; and to Tiny Tim who did not die, he was a second father. And so, as Tiny Tim observed, God bless us every one!... The End. Dickens bundles up the manuscript and rushes downstairs. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 90 91 92 93 94 95 96

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. DICKENS HOUSE
dialogues.text: Dickens rushes to the front door, manuscript in hand. Kat appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Charles? There’s someone here to see you.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Not now, Kate. I have to get this to the printers before nine o’clock-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tara is laughing and playing with the children.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Tara? How did you --

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: It were Mr. Dickens sir. He heard you were looking for me. Dickens looks at Kate.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Your father makes it his business to know things about people. Tara hands him back his book, Aladdin.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Thank you for the loan.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Did you like it? Tara brightens.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, sir. It was fizzing. This delights Dickens. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 97

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Fizzing! Delightful. You must read Robinson Crusoe next. Tara looks at him, in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tara. I’m sorry for sending you away. It was a mistake. Will you stay? Tara nods, moved. Dickens smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And by the way, you were right about Tiny Tim. He doesn’t die. Scrooge helps him to get better.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Of course. And doesn’t he help Scrooge get better, too?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: He does. He does, indeed. Dickens looks at the mantelpiece, where a magic lantern i sitting.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where did that come from?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: A gift. For the children. From your father.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: He was here?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You can still catch him if-- Dickens hesitates, then stuffs the manuscript into his ja as he rushes towards the door, turns around abruptly, gra Kate and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Kate--

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I know, you don’t deserve me. Go. He rushes out of the house. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the station, Dickens’ cab pulls up. He jumps out dashes past an enterprising VENDOR who is attempting to interest the passersby in his selection of “Christmas tre

dialogues.speaker: VENDOR
dialogues.text: ...the very latest, the same as what’s in the Queen’s own drawing room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens enters the station and sees his father and mother the platform about to get on the train. He leaps over the barrier and runs towards them.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Last call. All aboard.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Stop! A CONSTABLE sees him and blows his whistle.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: Stop! Mr. and Mrs. Dickens, just getting on the train, turn to their son running along the platform.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: What do you think you are doing?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Please, dear. Don’t make a scene. We're going away.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Oh, no you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: Hi! You! Mr. Dickens sees the Constable, rushing to catch up to th

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: What have I done?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Done? It’s what you haven’t done. Mrs. Dickens flinches. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 99

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: I don’t understand— Dickens laughs, a touch maniacally.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Who is going to carve the turkey? (to his mother) Who is going to make the Christmas pudding? It won’t be the same without you? Mrs. Dickens softens.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DICKENS
dialogues.text: Oh, the pudding. The secret is to warm the treacle first. Mr. Dickens turns to his wife.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DICKENS
dialogues.text: There you see, my dear? I told you something would turn up.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DICKENS
dialogues.text: (through tears) You did, you did. Dickens laughs again, joyfully. He embraces them warmly. The Constable has finally caught up with them. His eyes w in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: You’re that Charles Dickens.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Guilty.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: I’m a huge fan.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: That last one. Chuzzlewit. Wept like a baby, I did.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Well, that’s very— What is your name, Constable?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: My name? Copperfield, Sir. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: 97C
dialogues.text: 100 Dickens whips out his notebook of names.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Copperfield? Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: Any chance of a new book soon?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Eh? Dickens suddenly pats his coat, remembering the Christmas Carol manuscript stuffed in his jacket. He pulls it out a rushes for a cab.

dialogues.speaker: EXT TRAIN STATION
dialogues.text: Manuscript in hand , Dickens runs out of the train statio jumps in a cab.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Shoe Lane. And hurry.

dialogues.speaker: EXT PRINTERS
dialogues.text: Dickens arrives at the printer, just as the clock is stri ten. Forster is waiting for him on the street.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Charles. Where have you been? I’ve been waiting here for an hour.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: It’s all right. I have the manuscript. He pulls it out of his coat pocket. Several pages go flyi in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No! Forster and Dickens go chasing after the pages. A couple PASSERSBY stop to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forster and Dickens run through the halls, past the noisy press room, past the bookbinding room, to the Composing r A cranky, ink-stained compositor (MR. GRUB) is just setti up when the two men arrive, out of breath, with the manuscript. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Grub! We’re here. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 101 The compositor starts and drops a line of type on the flo

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: I have the ending! You can finish it now.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUB
dialogues.text: It’s too late.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Come on. You’ve already printed the other four chapters. It’s just one more. Please. Grub struggles with this.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUB
dialogues.text: I can’t guarantee anything.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUB
dialogues.text: (sourly) I didn’t say I could do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickens waits nervously. He straightens at the sight of Forster, making his way through the crowded room. Finally arrives at the table.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Well? For God’s sake man, don’t prolong the agony. Forster pulls out a package, wrapped in gold paper and ti with a bright red ribbon and hands it to Dickens. Dickens opens it carefully. Inside is the book. The cover red, the title stamped in gold: A Christmas Carol, By Cha Dickens. Dickens handles it with awe, turning the pages slowly.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s exactly as I’d imagined it.

dialogues.speaker: THACKERAY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello, gents. Extraordinary weather, isn’t it? Looks like snow. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 98 102 Dickens Thackeray. Thackeray holds up a galley copy of the Christmas Carol.

dialogues.speaker: THACKERAY
dialogues.text: What’s this I have? Why, it’s your new book. I’m going to review it for this evening’s Spectator. I’m told you wrote it in only six weeks, Charles? What a prodigy you are! Thackeray throws himself into a nearby armchair, opening book with a flourish. Dickens and Forster exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the parlour windows we see the first Christmas snowfall. The gleaming new chandelier takes pride of plac next to a Christmas tree as a splendid party is underway. Fanny, Henry Sr. and Junior are there, watching as Mr. Dickens, dressed as a conjuror, does some magic tricks fo Tara and the children. Mrs. Dickens chatters away to an uncomprehending Signor Mazzini. Mrs. Fisk has been into t punch.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FISK
dialogues.text: (humming to herself....) Kate appears.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Good heavens, what is that?

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: The Germans call it a Tannenbaum. Now that the royal family has one, it’s going to be all the rage. Grip, the raven, flies onto a branch and eyes Mrs. Fisk.

dialogues.speaker: GRIP
dialogues.text: Halloa, old girl. Halloa. Forster arrives, a blushing Charlotte in tow. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 99 103

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Miss Wigmore! Charlotte holds up her hand to show off her engagement ri

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Papa had a change of heart. Forster brandishes a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: Charles, I think you’1l want to hear this. It’s by Thackeray.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Not now please, Forster...

dialogues.speaker: FORSTER
dialogues.text: (ignoring charles) “It was a blessed inspiration that put such a book into the head of Charles Dickens...a happy inspiration of the heart, that warms every page. It is impossible to read without a glowing bosom and burning cheeks, between love and shame of our kind....” The group applauds. Smiling, Dickens holds up a glass of punch:

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls. He smiles at Kate.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...and those on the way. A toast: I wish you all many merry Christmases, friendships, great accumulation of cheerful recollections and heaven at last for all of us. At that moment, Grip sees an opportunity and flies up the staircase towards Dickens’ study. We follow him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRIP lands on the desk, revealing a happy Scrooge and the POSSE flicking through the newly printed book, giggling a the Leech print of the Fezziwigs. The Man Who Invented Christmas Yellow Revisions January 100 104

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In the season of hope, we will shut out nothing from our firesides and everyone will be welcome. Taking off once again GRIP flies through the open window out over the chimney tops of London... EXT. HATCHARD’S BOOKSTORE - NIGHT 100 .+. Grip lands on the Hatchard’s sign.

dialogues.speaker: DICKENS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Welcome what has been and what is, and what we hope may be, to this shelter underneath the holly. Happy, happy Christmas to one and all. Below, a line-up of people trail down the street and arou the corner, waiting to purchase their copy of The Carol. move up and up to reveal the wide snow filled streets of beautiful bustling Dickensian Christmas world.
